contentrichtext.text: {{For|the British flying ace|James Ira Thomas Jones}} {{Infobox military person | name = Ira Jones | image = irajones.jpg | image_size = 250 | caption = Ira Jones with Elvis Presley in Germany | birth_date = {{Birth date|1923|07|10}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|2004|07|11|1923|07|10}} | birth_place = [[Arkansas]] | death_place = [[Arkansas]] | placeofburial = | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | nickname = | birth_name = | allegiance = [[United States]] | branch = [[United States Army]] | serviceyears = | rank = [[First sergeant]] | servicenumber = | unit = [[U.S. 3rd Armored Division|3rd Armored Division]] | commands = | battles = [[World War II]] | battles_label = | awards = {{plainlist| *[[Bronze Star Medal|Bronze Star]] *[[Silver Star]] }} | relations = | laterwork = {{plainlist| *Author *Public speaker }} | signature = }} '''Ira Jones''' (July 10, 1923 â€“ July 11, 2004) was an author, best known as the first sergeant in charge of [[Elvis Presley]] for a portion of the time Elvis served in the army. Elvis drove Jones' [[jeep]] for nine months while the two were stationed together in [[Germany]]. Jones was also a veteran of [[World War II]] and a recipient of both the [[Bronze Star Medal|Bronze]] and [[Silver Star]]s. The two first met in the port city of [[Bremerhaven]], Germany, in the autumn of 1958 when Elvis was among the replacement troops arriving aboard the USS ''General Randall''. Elvis drove Jones in a jeep named "HQ 31" for nine months while serving in the Scout Platoon, [[1st Medium Tank Battalion]], 32nd Armor, of the [[U.S. 3rd Armored Division|3rd Armored Division]], part of the [[U.S. Seventh Army]]. Although Jones had no idea what Elvis looked like before they met, it has been reported that the two formed a close bond during their time together. [http://www.elvisinfonet.com/irajones.html 1] On May 6, 1959, Sgt Jones appeared on the popular television game show ''[[I've Got A Secret]]''. [[File:Soldier Boy Elvis (Ira Jones memoir - book cover).jpg|thumb|left|Cover for ''Soldier Boy Elvis'']] In 1978, Jones began writing a book about the time he spent with Elvis, entitled ''Soldier Boy Elvis''. The book was published in 1993. In the years that followed, Jones became a regular speaker at Elvis-related conventions, Bill E. Burk's [[Elvis World]] breakfasts and fan club meetings all over the world including in Germany. Jones appeared in numerous television specials, documentaries and videos including the short-lived newsmagazine ''Instant Recall'', hosted by [[John Palmer (TV journalist)|John Palmer]], former news anchor from NBC's ''[[Today (NBC program)|The Today Show]]'' and the 2001 documentary ''[[Remembering Elvis: A Documentary]]'' [http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0791191/], which also included interviews with comedian [[Steve Allen]] and others. Jones died of a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] in July 2004 in the [[United States|U.S.]] [[U.S. state|state]] of [[Arkansas]] where he grew up. ==Bibliography== * ''Soldier Boy Elvis'' (1993 ISBN 1-879207-23-0) ==External links== *[http://www.elvis.com.au/presley/uploads/ira_jones_elvis.jpg Photo of Elvis with Jones] *[http://www.elvisinfonet.com/irajones.html Bill E.
